thinking.disposable_income: Median income is $58,647, with 45.6% households earning less than $50,000. This suggests moderate to limited disposable income for many residents, making them sensitive to additional transportation costs and taxes
thinking.discretionary_consumption: Given the income distribution and household sizes, many families likely have limited discretionary spending capacity. A significant portion of income goes to essential needs, making residents sensitive to any additional taxes or fees
thinking.accessibility: The area shows high car dependency with 87.4% of households having at least one vehicle and 65.2% driving alone to work. Only 10.8% use transit, suggesting limited transit accessibility. The community needs balanced policies that don't overly burden drivers while improving transit service
thinking.decision_rationale: 1. Prioritized proposals with lower sales tax (0.5%) due to limited disposable income. 2. Favored moderate driving fees ($0.50) over high fees ($1.00) given high car dependency. 3. Selected proposals with lower transit fares ($0.75-$1.25) to support transit-dependent residents. 4. Balanced travel time improvements with cost impacts. 5. Considered the large proportion of working-class and middle-income households who would be sensitive to cost increases
